author: muhammad.ibrahim
title: India‚Äôs series dream ends in three-day defeat by South Africa
text:
CENTURION: India‚Äôs dream of winning a Test series in South Africa for the first time was ended inside three days as they crashed to an innings and 32 runs defeat at SuperSport Park in Centurion on Thursday.
With the series consisting of only two matches they can at best earn a share of the honors if they win the second Test starting in Cape Town on Wednesday.
India crashed to 131 all out in their second innings after conceding a 163-run first innings lead.
A day which started with the match evenly poised turned into a rout for the tourists.
Dean Elgar (185) and Marco Jansen (84 not out) transformed a slender 11-run lead for South Africa at the start of play into a strong position.
They shared a 111-run sixth wicket partnership as South Africa took an overnight 256 for five to 408 all out despite the absent of injured captain Temba Bavuma.
Virat Kohli hit an aggressive 76 for India before he was last man out but the rest of the batting collapsed against South Africa‚Äôs fast bowlers on a lively pitch.
The second innings lasted just 34.1 overs. Kohli hit 12 fours and a six in an 82-ball innings. Shubman Gill made 26 but no other batsman scored more than six.
Kagiso Rabada set the tone for South Africa, bowling Sharma for a duck with a superb delivery which deviated off the pitch to hit the off stump.
Rabada, who took five for 59 in the first innings, took two for 32 and finished the match with an outstanding diving catch at long-on to dismiss Kohli off Jansen, who took three for 36.
Left-arm fast bowler Nandre Burger completed an impressive debut Test by taking four for 33, giving hm match figures of seven for 83.
Three catches went down in the slip cordon but none proved expensive.
Elgar was named man of the match in his final Test on his home ground. He has announced he will retire from international cricket after the second Test.
‚ÄúIt was pretty special for me,‚Äù he said.
‚ÄúIt (the pitch) was pretty juicy. You‚Äôve got to keep it nice and simple batting in Tests. Focus on the ball, play straight and play late.‚Äù
It was a policy which India were unable to follow, although Sharma paid tribute to KL Rahul for his ‚Äúbrilliant‚Äù century in the first innings.
Bavuma took no further part in the match after injuring his left hamstring on the first morning. A statement from Cricket South Africa said it had been decided he would not bat because of concern about him aggravating the injury.
There was no indication whether Bavuma would be fit for the second Test.
Elgar captained the team on the field after Bavuma‚Äôs injury and, having captained South Africa in 17 Tests, he would be favorite to take over the leadership in his final Test if Bavuma is not fit.

author: Rosie Romero, Host and Owner of RosieontheHouse.com
title: How Arizonan homeowners can harness the sun‚Äôs power
text:
ROSIE ON THE HOUSE
How Arizonan homeowners can harness the sun‚Äôs power Jul 18, 2024, 3:00 PM
Why not take advantage of Arizona's famously strong sunshine? (Pexels file photo)
(Pexels file photo)
Share
BY ROSIE ROMERO, HOST AND OWNER OF ROSIEONTHEHOUSE.COM
KTAR.com
When we mention solar, most people immediately think of ‚Äúenergy source.‚Äù While true, we use the sun‚Äôs power in many different ways.
Before we get started, it might be a good idea to refresh our knowledge about how the seasons affect how we use the sun.
Since Galileo, we know that earth orbits the sun. We also know the earth‚Äôs rotational axis is on an angle of 23.5 degrees. That angle means that as the earth orbits the sun, the northern and southern hemispheres are either tilting toward the sun or away from it. This tilt, as it moves between its extreme points in the orbit, determines the seasons, and the angle that sunlight comes through our windows. When winter in Arizona arrives, the sun is lower in the sky and falls more deeply inside our home. In the summertime, the sun is higher as the earth‚Äôs northern hemisphere leans into the sun, cutting off the light entering our homes.
This is why many of our homes have eaves or overhangs. The deeper the overhang, the more sunlight stays out of our window in the summer months. There are many ways we can control the sun‚Äôs ability to assist us. From overhangs, to landscaping there are tools to help us best use the sun.
Much of the sun‚Äôs power comes from its light Since the first buildings, we have had these devices we call windows . The primary function of these inventions is to let in light from the sun and air. Windows have improved exponentially over the past five thousand or so years, but they help us light our homes, at least during the daytime. We can choose the locations of our windows based on how we want a room to be lit at different times of the year. By planting deciduous trees, the right distance from our home, we can get the best of both worlds. Leaves for shade in summer, no leaves for sunlight to reach us in the winter.
How to take advantage of shade We can passively control how we use the sun. Shade structures allow us to block out the direct rays of the sun.
Let‚Äôs look at some uses of shade.
Shaded areas still benefit from indirect light of the sun without the direct glare of sunlight. The eaves on our homes help us benefit from appropriate seasonal use of sunlight. We all know the sun is higher in the sky during the summer months and lower in the winter. The depth of the eave will dictate when the direct sunlight hits our outside walls and enters through our windows and doors. Shade structures over our outdoor areas are very popular in Arizona and afford us the ability to be outside without the often harsh Arizona sun. Window shades are another simple tool we use to control the direct rays of the in our homes. The ‚ÄúRosie Right‚Äù way to do this is to cover the entire window frame as well as the glass area. Window frames can be as heat conductive, or even more so, than the glass surface. The screen should be installed with an air gap between it and the window. You never want any part of the screen fabric or its frame to be in contact with the window glass surface or its frame. See our take on trees above. Those are some of the low-tech or passive ways we use the sun.
Our pets are skilled at taking advantage of the sun. A cat lying on a window ledge drinking up the sunlight or a dog finding a special patch on the floor will change positions as the sun moves and the patch relocates.
Who among us recall the solar clothes dryers our Mom‚Äôs used to use? That actually is a question we would love to get your answer to. Email us at info@rosieonthehouse.com !
Technology to the rescue Technology allows us to utilize the sun in many new ways. The early years of solar collection just allowed us to get hot water for indoor use and transfer heat for warming our homes. The roof-mounted collectors were a bit clunky and prone to leaks. The piping has been greatly improved and thus, a better heat transfer.
By and large, heating a liquid with sunlight and transferring that heat has given way to photovoltaics. That is harnessing the sun‚Äôs light to produce electricity. Perhaps today this is the most common application of solar technology .
We have come a long way from ancient methods of manipulating direct sunlight to using rooftop photovoltaic panels and a sophisticated battery storage system in our garage to harness the power of the sun. However, we shouldn‚Äôt forget about simpler solar technologies that led us to where we are today.

author: Jimmy Meiklejohn
title: Bryan Lucas and Scott Rohrich to coach Henwood Park in 2025
text:
Henwood Park have unveiled their new Pascoe Cup coaching line-up for next season.
After a couple of years away from senior football, Bryan Lucas and [Scott Rohrich](https://www.dailyadvertiser.com.au/story/7301134/wagga-united-search-for-the-right-combinations/) are taking on the job as co-coaches.
The pair have a fair bit of experience coaching at both junior and senior level and take over the role vacated by [Jake Ploenges.](https://www.dailyadvertiser.com.au/story/8251706/ploenges-to-coach-henwood-park-in-hopeful-return-to-pascoe-cup/)
Lucas said he was excited about taking on the role and working alongside Rohrich at the Hawks.
"I'm looking forward to it," Lucas said.
"Scott and I had a chat about getting into it together as we've both had a couple of years off.
"I'm really excited to get back into it."
Lucas revealed he's been thinking of getting back into senior football coaching for a couple of years and noted he believed the time was now right to step back into a top role.
"I've been looking to get back into it for a couple of years," he said.
"I've been helping a mate out at CSU with the Aussie Rules for a couple of years just to see what they do and learn about their program.
"I just thought this year was the right year and I'm ready to go."
Rohrich was also eager for the upcoming season and he noted that he and Lucas work extremely well with one another.
"We've coached previously with each other," Rohrich said.
"I first met Bryan when he coached my son, I came along just to watch games and I ended up getting dragged in along Bryan where we spent a good three years after that together.
"We found that we work really well together then after that we coached at different clubs and against each other which was quite amusing at times.
"We've got a bit of a background with the juniors, I've also coached senior women's for a couple of years then did one year coaching senior men.
"I then stepped away for three years I think it has been now, Bryan and I keep in touch and we've been talking about getting back into it on and off over a few beers.
"We had a few players approach us saying they wanted us back so we had a little talk and we've come over to the club.
"It's very exciting and I'm looking forward to it, we're getting the old coaching team back together.
"It's going to be fun and a few of the players we've coached over the years at Wanderers are either at this club or coming over to the club.
"We're going to know some faces and meet some new."
With their experience in coaching juniors, Lucas added they are extremely interested in making the most of Henwood Park's solid junior system.
"We're quite excited about bringing the juniors through," he said.
"This club has a great junior system and we want to be able to push them through and give them the tools to push themselves into senior football with the new 18's comp which should be good.
"Players that are looking to come back to the club or new players that want to join the club, we're more than happy to have a chat to them.
"Just reach out to one of us and we can go from there."
Henwood Park senior vice president James Thompson was delighted to have Lucas and Rohrich on board for next season.
"After what Jake (Ploenges) did last year in building a foundation for the club I think it was pivotal that we got some good coaches in," Thompson said.
"Bryan and Scott have worked together for a number of years and they have good connections with some of the players at the club already.
"I think that's going to go a long way in building the club up from what it already has as well as bringing in other players as well."
The Hawks had a solid first season back in the Pascoe Cup competition in 2024 and Thompson was hoping to build on that progress next year.
"I think we built a very good team culture within the club and that's what we want to continue to build on," he said.
"Results last year may not have gone our way, but I think as a club and specifically as a first and reserve grade team we built off each other.
"I think that's a big credit to Jake (Ploenges) for last year and Bryan and Scott are the best candidates to keep pushing that forward in 2025."

author: Pedro Socorro
title: Una tragedia familiar golpea La Aldea y Juncalillo
text:
Una tragedia familiar golpea La Aldea y Juncalillo
Cuatro hermanos, con edades comprendidas entre los 22 y los 16 a√±os, naturales de Jucalillo, murieron abrasados en el incendio de un almac√©n de La Aldea en 1951
El 25 de abril de 1951, una tragedia familiar conmocion√≥ a los habitantes de La Aldea de San Nicol√°s. Cuatro hermanos, naturales de Jucalillo, que dorm√≠an en un almac√©n de la zona de Los Manantiales murieron abrasados en un incendio que se origin√≥ durante la madrugada. El mayor ten√≠a 22 a√±os; el m√°s peque√±o, solo 16. No pudieron abandonar el viejo cuarto a tiempo. Sus cad√°veres quedaron api√±ados junto a la puerta de entrada.
Aquel suceso cre√≥ en el √°nimo del pueblo aldeano un hueco no s√≥lo para la tristeza y el desasosiego, sino tambi√©n para las interrogaciones. Todav√≠a hoy nadie se explica lo ocurrido a los cuatro hijos de la familia de Nicolasa Carrillo Mart√≠n y Manuel Garc√≠a Saavedra, el segundo motorista de la presa Los P√©rez, en aquella noche del 25 de abril de 1951. Conformaban una familia verdaderamente numerosa. Do√±a Nicolasa hab√≠a dado a luz a una docena de hijos.
En aquella primavera, cuatro de sus hijos ‚Äîlos hermanos Manuel, Matilde, Crist√≥bal y Francisco Garc√≠a Carrillo, de veintid√≥s, veinte, dieciocho y diecis√©is a√±os respectivamente‚Äî abandonaron su casa de Juncalillo, en G√°ldar, para trabajar en la zafra tomatera, concretamente en la propiedad que don Rafael Rodr√≠guez, conocido por el Pistolera, pose√≠a en La Aldea. El resto de la familia se qued√≥ en la cumbre. Una vez all√≠, se alojaron en un cuarto-almac√©n de la finca, situada en Los Manantiales, en condiciones precarias, como la mayor√≠a de los temporeros de entonces.
Aquella noche murieron abrasados. Seg√∫n la historia, una vela con la que se alumbraban encendi√≥ la tragedia. Fue una muerte ag√≥nica. A pesar de sus esfuerzos, no pudieron salir de aquel viejo cuarto. A la ma√±ana siguiente, los cuatro hermanos fueron hallados carbonizados junto a la puerta. Sus cad√°veres quedaron tan destrozados que solo un ata√∫d bast√≥ para acogerlos.
Familia abatida
La noticia abati√≥ al matrimonio Garc√≠a Carrillo, que acudi√≥ de urgencia hasta el pueblo aldeano para hacerse cargo del entierro en el viejo cementerio. Manuel y Nicolasa nunca superaron la tragedia. No pod√≠a ser de otro modo. Aquel tr√°gico suceso quedar√≠a marcado a fuego y llanto en su memoria hasta que la muerte borr√≥ tambi√©n su existencia.
Curiosamente, el hecho no fue investigado con profundidad a pesar de la intervenci√≥n judicial; y a√∫n no se sabe la verdad pues, en su momento, todo fueron conjeturas sin comprobar. Para colmo, la poblaci√≥n campesina, que constitu√≠a, y con mucho, la mayor√≠a del municipio, se hallaba totalmente desprotegida, sin derechos, y sometida a un r√©gimen dictatorial.
La Justicia cerr√≥ el caso sin encontrar indicios de criminalidad. Y, por si fuera poco, la familia no recibi√≥ ning√∫n tipo de indemnizaci√≥n porque, seg√∫n relatan sus descendientes, en las diligencias instruidas por el juzgado de Gu√≠a, alguien se hizo pasar por el padre de familia, analfabeto, y firm√≥ un documento en el que renunciaba a cualquier compensaci√≥n.
Seg√∫n Francisco Su√°rez Moreno, cronista oficial de La Aldea de San Nicol√°s, quien ha realizado un estudio sobre la siniestralidad en la sociedad tradicional (1801‚Äì1969) de su municipio, los hermanos se despertaron alrededor de las tres de la madrugada y, ante el incendio, gritaron e intentaron salir por la puerta sin conseguirlo. Los lamentos fueron o√≠dos por alg√∫n vecino que crey√≥ que se trataba de discusiones entre hermanos. ‚ÄúLo cierto es que, desesperados, no pudieron abrir la puerta y perecieron carbonizados junto a ella‚Äù, asegura.
No obstante, las inc√≥gnitas de este suceso a√∫n se mantienen: ¬ødejaron al dormir alguna lumbre encendida y √©sta fue en verdad la que provoc√≥ el incendio? ¬øEl cuarto estaba trancado? ¬øEl fuego se aviv√≥ por efectos de un bid√≥n de combustible? ¬øPor qu√© no pudieron forzar la puerta? Son preguntas a las que el avezado cronista aldeano no ha encontrado, desde aquel tiempo, las oportunas respuestas; o, al menos, las m√°s razonables.
El Pistolera, un rico e influyente propietario agr√≠cola natural de G√°ldar, los ten√≠a all√≠ de trabajadores y los cuidaba como a su familia. No en vano era el padrino de Matilde, una de las v√≠ctimas. La gente cree que se durmieron con la vela encendida. En el cuarto hab√≠a un bid√≥n de gasoil o gasolina para el motor, lo que provoc√≥ que el incendio alcanzara cotas de desgracia. El humo los asfixi√≥ y encendi√≥ el misterio.
Abandonaron Juncalillo con el sue√±o de poder trabajar.
La prensa censurada de la √©poca no ofreci√≥ a sus lectores ni un solo detalle de este luctuoso suceso. Quince d√≠as m√°s tarde, sin embargo, Falange abr√≠a su portada con la noticia de que el gobernador civil y jefe provincial del Movimiento, don Jos√© Garc√≠a Hern√°ndez, visitaba oficialmente La Aldea. El gobernador, acompa√±ado de su s√©quito, se mostr√≥ entusiasta al ver un arco de flores frente al ayuntamiento con una gran pancarta que dec√≠a: ‚ÄúLa Aldea de San Nicol√°s expresa su gratitud a don Jos√© Garc√≠a Hern√°ndez, gobernador civil de Las Palmas. La presa nos convertir√° en una gran ciudad. Por siempre Franco. ¬°Arriba Espa√±a!‚Äù
La presa El Caidero de la Ni√±a, que se termin√≥ de construir en 1958, seg√∫n el proyecto de Luis de Casa Calzada, era una justa ilusi√≥n de la comunidad de regantes a fin de lograr mayores beneficios para su agricultura. Y es que La Aldea viv√≠a entonces un despegue econ√≥mico en el sector primario, con la reanudaci√≥n de los cultivos de tomate.
Hasta all√≠ llegaban familias de vida humilde y andariega, desde otros pueblos de la isla o de Fuerteventura, siempre a la b√∫squeda de nuevos horizontes donde poder mejorar y salir de su m√≠sera existencia. Para entonces, el Pistolera era un propietario de aquella fase expansiva del capitalismo agrario local. Son a√±os en los que La Aldea crece en poblaci√≥n y se abre al exterior gracias a notables mejoras en las comunicaciones, con la carretera de Mog√°n y sus tramos hacia las playas de Tasarte y Tasartico.
La familia Garc√≠a Carrillo fue una de los tantos temporeros que acudieron hasta La Aldea. Y es que cuando la miseria acosa puede obligar al estilo de vida itinerante; una realidad que mantiene su vigencia en la actualidad.
Manuel, Matilde, Crist√≥bal y Francisco Garc√≠a Carrillo estaban en la edad en la que los sue√±os son posibles, pero el incendio seg√≥ sus vidas.
‚ÄúMi madre lloraba al verme‚Äù
Salvador Garc√≠a Carrillo, un hist√≥rico del PSOE en Canarias que falleci√≥ en octubre de 2024, era el hermano menor de las v√≠ctimas. Conoci√≥ la cara del infortunio: la desesperaci√≥n del padre, los gritos de su madre, los llantos de su hermano Daniel, que andaba por los ocho a√±os. √âl era todav√≠a un chiquillo, de siete a√±os, pero ya con la edad suficiente para atisbar que algo estaba ocurriendo en su entorno familiar. ‚ÄúCuando aquella desgracia de mi familia yo estaba internado en el seminario viejo, en Las Palmas. Y recuerdo que mi madre se echaba a llorar cada vez que ven√≠a a verme, sin saber bien por qu√©. Dos a√±os despu√©s, tras mucho preguntar por mis hermanos, mi madre me lo cont√≥ todo‚Äù, rememoraba Salvador Garc√≠a Carrillo en diciembre de 2009. Su madre, Nicolasa Carrillo, qued√≥ afectada para siempre por la tremenda experiencia sufrida. ‚ÄúMi madre nunca se recuper√≥ de las depresiones‚Äù, lamentaba el pol√≠tico.

author: Matthew Dlamini
title: NamWater suspends irrigation water supply from Hardap Dam due to drought
text:
Namwater suspended the process of drawing water for irrigation from the Hardap Dam on Thursday.
This is due to low levels of water in the dam attributed to drought, said NamWater spokesperson Lot Ndamanomhata in a media statement on Thursday.
‚ÄúThis decision, however, does not affect the drinking water supply to the Mariental municipality or surrounding communities,‚Äù he said.
According to Ndamanomhata, the measure aligns with NamWater‚Äôs commitment to secure water reserves for essential use, including potable and livestock needs.
It ensures adequate supply until the projected dry run date of February 2026, he added.
‚ÄúRecent consultations and analysis were undertaken with stakeholders to assess the availability of ‚Äòdead storage‚Äô water, allowing irrigation water supply through October 2024. Beyond this point, remaining reserves will be prioritised for human consumption and livestock needs.‚Äù
NamWater recognises the critical need for water conservation during these times and encourages all Namibians to save water, especially as the
Hardap Dam levels remain under pressure, noted Ndamanomhata.
‚ÄúWe reassure residents that this move is a proactive approach to managing the region‚Äôs water resources responsibly.‚Äù
He said NamWater will continue to monitor the situation closely.
‚ÄúWe remain committed to balancing the needs of agricultural producers, residents and the local economy,‚Äù he added.

text:
